subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
msgSnippet: I would recommend against using an o even for a private work-around when that is not the sound needed for the word.  In my opinion, you want to indelibly
messageBody:
I would recommend against using an "o" even for a private "work-around" when that is not the sound needed for the word.  In my opinion, you want to indelibly link the QS letters with the sounds they represent in your mind to foster automatic reading, i.e. without the necessity of sounding out words.  After all, this is what we do with T.O.

I think the use of a letter that represents a different sound in place of the correct letter, would be counter productive and harmful to your comprehension.  I would just advise you to realize that QS does not require that every letter be joined to every other letter.  QS is quite cursive as Read designed it.  The small amount of time required for the occasional pen-lift, is not worth the confusion of muddying the phonemic character, might I say, "purity," of the alphabet.

Just my two cents.


Paige Gabhart


On 8/18/2011 12:12 PM, cossyrosario wrote:
 

Thanks, Sid.

The reason why I didn't use this work-around is because I've been trying to follow the QuikScript rule that the letters represent sounds of the English language.

In com- con- the o sound is like the u in utter (as in commend, contend), or like the o in ox (compliment, conscious). The o when written as in Latin letters (as a circle) has the sound of owe in owe. Therefore com- with the circle o would rhyme with comb, and con- with the circle o would rhyme with cone, which is not what I want to.

However, if I were making notes for myself, as is the case most of the time I use QuikScript, I could certainly use the o as a private work-around.

What I have been using as an even shorter work-around for temporary private notes (to-do list, notes of a meeting discussion to be transcribed fairly soon on the computer) is just the k as a prefix, thus kputer for computer, kshus for conscious, etc.
